title: Brit wins legal fight against Australia ‘backpacker tax’ that could help up to 80,000
text:
Catherine Addy says it’s unfair visitors in Australia are ‘taxed more harshly’ for the same work

Thousands of holidaymakers who stay to work Down Under could be entitled to millions in tax refunds after a visitor from London won a court battle today.

Drama student Catherine Addy, 27, came to Australia on a work visa in 2015, visiting Cairns and Brisbane before renting at a shared house in Sydney.

She took on the taxman after not being exempt from tax on the first AU$18,200 (£9693) she earned – as all Australian citizens are.

The judge ruling her case in Australia’s Federal Court accused the Australian Tax Office (ATO) as ‘discrimination based on nationality’, meaning the British backpacker is entitled to a refund of AU$2,200.

If this amount was paid to the 80,000 working tourists in Oz, the government could face a bill of AU$176 million (£93,806,240).

The historic payout could see many other working holidaymakers demanding refunds

The judge said her treatment was ‘a disguised form of discrimination based on nationality’

Those holding a 462 or 471 visa have to pay 15 per cent for every dollar up until AU$37,000 (£19,723) under laws introduced in January 2017.

But the AU$18,200 tax exemption should still apply to anyone living at a permanent address, regardless of their citizenship, as they are classed as residents for tax purposes.

Justice Logan said renting at a house share at the Earlwood area of Sydney meant Ms Addy should not have paid AU$3,100 (£1652) tax on the £11027 she earned in 2016/17 before flying back to London.

He blasted the ATO for treating her unfairly because she was British and called her tax bill ‘a disguised form of discrimination based on nationality’.

Based on the ruling, she should have started paying 19 per cent in tax between the first AU$18,201 (£9,705) and AU$37,000 (£19,730) she made like an Australian citizen.

Ms Addy, originally from Bexleyheath, southeast London, worked on a horse farm in Western Australia in 2016 before becoming a waitress at Novotel hotels and Sydney’s Menzies.

She was ruled as having been a resident for tax purposes while she was working

This entitled her to the same AU$18,200 tax exemption as Australian citizens

After the ruling, she told ABC News: ‘I think it is wrong that foreigners should be taxed more harshly than Australians when they are doing the same work.’

Tax agent H&R Block director of tax communications Mark Chapman told Daily Mail Australia: ‘We’ve had a steady procession of these people through our doors arguing that this tax rate is not fair.

‘All those people, if this judgement stands, will have cause to go back to the ATO and say, “Thanks very much, you’ve got our tax wrong, we’ll have our extra refund please”.’

‘In the context of these working holidaymakers, this is a really significant judgement.’

An ATO spokeswoman said they will consider the decision before deciding whether to appeal.

She added: ”We consider most working holiday makers are not residents for tax purposes and this decision has no impact for these working holidaymakers.’

description: British backpacker Catherine Addy was deprived of tax exemption under her Australian working holiday visa despite being a resident for tax purposes.
